review.title: Efficient Delivery Policy to Minimize User Traffic Consumption in Guaranteed Advertising
review.abstract: In this work, we study the guaranteed delivery model which is widely used in online display advertising. In the guaranteed delivery scenario, ad exposures (which are also called impressions in some works) to users are guaranteed by contracts signed in advance between advertisers and publishers. A crucial problem for the advertising platform is how to fully utilize the valuable user traffic to generate as much as possible revenue.

sections.heading: Contributions
sections.text: In this thesis, we propose a practical consumption minimization model for the delivery guarantee. Within this model, we provide the theoretical analysis and design an almost optimal delivery policy. Our contributions consist mainly of two parts, which are listed as the following. Theoretical analyses for optimal expected delivery of user consumption. By using some basic results at the end of the theory, we prove that the optimal offline consumption of user traffic is lower limited by an expected flow (THEOREM 1). This proves to be very useful for measuring the performance of delivery policy. In addition, we construct an optimal online delivery policy based on a recursion. However, solving this recursion requires an exponential time, which motivates us to design a more efficient approximation of delivery policy. Efficient near-optimal delivery policy. Inspired by some insights derived from the proof of a lower limit for optimal offline traffic consumption, we design a flow-based delivery policy that has as few advantages as possible for all users (this HALM delivery policy).

sections.heading: Consumption Minimization Model
sections.text: In a Guaranteed Scenario (GD), users are divided into a number of atomic types, identified by their characteristics (e.g. geographical, gender, age, etc.). (This means that each user who visits the publishing platform can belong to only one unique type.) Each advertiser has one or more ad campaigns, and each campaign corresponds to a contract with an publisher. The contract specifies how often the corresponding ad should be exposed and how many user types this platform can be used. (See Figure 1 as an example.) The first ad campaign retains 200,000 exposures, and all users aged 20 to 25 years are targets of this campaign. So if a user meets this requirement, the corresponding ad can be displayed to that user. Formally speaking, the ad campaigns and user types relationship are modeled as a demand chart G = (A, U, E) with the objectives of this campaign.

sections.heading: Conclusions and Future Works
sections.text: In this paper, we examine the issue of minimising consumption for user traffic (CMPUT), which lies at the core of the DG scenario. We set a lower limit for optimal offline user traffic by using an expected flow of data that proves useful for performance evaluation, and then propose a flow-based delivery policy, which uses almost as little user traffic as possible to fulfil all contracts under realistic conditions. More importantly, it is robust in terms of estimation errors in the distribution of user types, and proves to be very useful for ordering and traffic management. Our flow-based delivery policy can be expanded to address other issues in DG, such as representation and smooth delivery. Nevertheless, there is still some work to be done, so that there can be a window of time for each advertiser indicating the start and deadline of the ad campaign. Another interesting issue is how the delivery guidelines will be designed, rather than how they will also come out of the delivery guidelines.

metadata.abstractText: In this work, we study the guaranteed delivery model which is widely used in online display advertising. In the guaranteed delivery scenario, ad exposures (which are also called impressions in some works) to users are guaranteed by contracts signed in advance between advertisers and publishers. A crucial problem for the advertising platform is how to fully utilize the valuable user traffic to generate as much as possible revenue. Different from previous works which usually minimize the penalty of unsatisfied contracts and some other cost (e.g. representativeness), we propose the novel consumption minimization model, in which the primary objective is to minimize the user traffic consumed to satisfy all contracts. Under this model, we develop a near optimal method to deliver ads for users. The main advantage of our method lies in that it consumes nearly as least as possible user traffic to satisfy all contracts, therefore more contracts can be accepted to produce more revenue. It also enables the publishers to estimate how much user traffic is redundant or short so that they can sell or buy this part of traffic in bulk in the exchange market. Furthermore, it is robust with regard to priori knowledge of user type distribution. Finally, the simulation shows that our method outperforms the traditional state-of-the-art methods.
